im_process_loc.h

00001 /** \file
00002  * \brief Image Processing - Local Operations
00003  *
00004  * See Copyright Notice in im_lib.h
00005  */
00006 
00007 #ifndef __IM_PROCESS_LOC_H
00008 #define __IM_PROCESS_LOC_H
00009

00017 
00018 /** \defgroup resize Image Resize
00019  * \par
00020  * Operations to change the image size. \n
00021  * All size operations include the alpha channel if any.
00022  * \par
00023  * See \ref im_process_loc.h
00024  * \ingroup process */
00025 
00026 /** Only reduze the image size using the given decimation order. \n
00027  * Supported decimation orders:
00028  * \li 0 - zero order (mean) 
00029  * \li 1 - first order (bilinear decimation)
00030  * Images must be of the same type. If image type is IM_MAP or IM_BINARY, must use order=0. \n
00031  * Returns zero if the counter aborted.
00032  *
00033  * \verbatim im.ProcessReduce(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, order: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00034  * \verbatim im.ProcessReduceNew(image: imImage, width, height, order: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00035  * \ingroup resize */
00036 int imProcessReduce(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int order);
00037 
00038 /** Change the image size using the given interpolation order. \n
00039  * Supported interpolation orders:
00040  * \li 0 - zero order (near neighborhood) 
00041  * \li 1 - first order (bilinear interpolation) 
00042  * \li 3 - third order (bicubic interpolation)
00043  * Images must be of the same type. If image type is IM_MAP or IM_BINARY, must use order=0. \n
00044  * Returns zero if the counter aborted.
00045  *
00046  * \verbatim im.ProcessResize(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, order: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00047  * \verbatim im.ProcessResizeNew(image: imImage, width, height, order: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00048  * \ingroup resize */
00049 int imProcessResize(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int order);
00050 
00051 /** Reduze the image area by 4 (w/2,h/2). \n
00052  * Images must be of the same type. Destiny image size must be source image width/2, height/2.
00053  * Can not operate on IM_MAP nor IM_BINARY images.
00054  *
00055  * \verbatim im.ProcessReduceBy4(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00056  * \verbatim im.ProcessReduceBy4New(image: imImage) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00057  * \ingroup resize */
00058 void imProcessReduceBy4(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image);
00059 
00060 /** Extract a rectangular region from an image. \n
00061  * Images must be of the same type. Destiny image size must be smaller than source image width-xmin, height-ymin. \n
00062  * ymin and xmin must be >0 and <size.
00063  *
00064  * \verbatim im.ProcessCrop(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, xmin: number, ymin: number) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00065  * \verbatim im.ProcessCropNew(image: imImage, xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax: number) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00066  * \ingroup resize */
00067 void imProcessCrop(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int xmin, int ymin);
00068 
00069 /** Insert a rectangular region in an image. \n
00070  * Images must be of the same type. Region image size can be larger than source image. \n
00071  * ymin and xmin must be >0 and <size. \n
00072  * Source and destiny must be of the same size. Can be done in-place.
00073  *
00074  * \verbatim im.ProcessInsert(src_image: imImage, region_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, xmin: number, ymin: number) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00075  * \verbatim im.ProcessInsertNew(image: imImage, region_image: imImage, xmin: number, ymin: number) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00076  * \ingroup resize */
00077 void imProcessInsert(const imImage* src_image, const imImage* region_image, imImage* dst_image, int xmin, int ymin);
00078 
00079 /** Increase the image size by adding pixels with zero value. \n
00080  * Images must be of the same type. Destiny image size must be greatter or equal than source image width+xmin, height+ymin.
00081  *
00082  * \verbatim im.ProcessAddMargins(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, xmin: number, ymin: number) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00083  * \verbatim im.ProcessAddMarginsNew(image: imImage, xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax: number) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00084  * \ingroup resize */
00085 void imProcessAddMargins(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int xmin, int ymin);
00086 
00087 
00088 
00089 /** \defgroup geom Geometric Operations
00090  * \par
00091  * Operations to change the shape of the image. \n
00092  * All geometric operations include the alpha channel if any.
00093  * \par
00094  * See \ref im_process_loc.h
00095  * \ingroup process */
00096 
00097 /** Calculates the size of the new image after rotation.
00098  *
00099  * \verbatim im.ProcessCalcRotateSize(width: number, height: number, cos0: number, sin0: number) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00100  * \ingroup geom */
00101 void imProcessCalcRotateSize(int width, int height, int *new_width, int *new_height, double cos0, double sin0);
00102 
00103 /** Rotates the image using the given interpolation order (see \ref imProcessResize). \n
00104  * Images must be of the same type. The destiny size can be calculated using \ref imProcessCalcRotateSize to fit the new image size, 
00105  * or can be any size, including the original size. The rotation is relative to the center of the image. \n
00106  * Returns zero if the counter aborted.
00107  *
00108  * \verbatim im.ProcessRotate(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, cos0: number, sin0: number, order: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00109  * \verbatim im.ProcessRotateNew(image: imImage, cos0, sin0, order: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00110  * \ingroup geom */
00111 int imProcessRotate(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, double cos0, double sin0, int order);
00112 
00113 /** Rotates the image using the given interpolation order (see \ref imProcessResize). \n
00114  * Images must be of the same type. Destiny can have any size, including the original size. \n
00115  * The rotation is relative to the reference point. But the result can be shifted to the origin. \n
00116  * Returns zero if the counter aborted.
00117  *
00118  * \verbatim im.ProcessRotateRef(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, cos0: number, sin0: number, x: number, y: number, to_origin: boolean, order: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00119  * \verbatim im.ProcessRotateRefNew(image: imImage, cos0: number, sin0: number, x: number, y: number, to_origin: boolean, order: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00120  * \ingroup geom */
00121 int imProcessRotateRef(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, double cos0, double sin0, int x, int y, int to_origin, int order);
00122 
00123 /** Rotates the image in 90 degrees counterclockwise or clockwise. Swap columns by lines. \n
00124  * Images must be of the same type. Destiny width and height must be source height and width. \n
00125  * Direction can be clockwise (1) or counter clockwise (-1).
00126  *
00127  * \verbatim im.ProcessRotate90(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, dir_clockwise: boolean) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00128  * \verbatim im.ProcessRotate90New(image: imImage, dir_clockwise: boolean) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00129  * \ingroup geom */
00130 void imProcessRotate90(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int dir_clockwise);
00131 
00132 /** Rotates the image in 180 degrees. Swap columns and swap lines. \n
00133  * Images must be of the same type and size.
00134  *
00135  * \verbatim im.ProcessRotate180(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00136  * \verbatim im.ProcessRotate180New(image: imImage) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00137  * \ingroup geom */
00138 void imProcessRotate180(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image);
00139 
00140 /** Mirror the image in a horizontal flip. Swap columns. \n
00141  * Images must be of the same type and size.
00142  * Can be done in-place.
00143  *
00144  * \verbatim im.ProcessMirror(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00145  * \verbatim im.ProcessMirrorNew(image: imImage) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00146  * \ingroup geom */
00147 void imProcessMirror(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image);
00148 
00149 /** Apply a vertical flip. Swap lines. \n
00150  * Images must be of the same type and size.
00151  * Can be done in-place.
00152  *
00153  * \verbatim im.ProcessFlip(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00154  * \verbatim im.ProcessFlipNew(image: imImage) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00155  * \ingroup geom */
00156 void imProcessFlip(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image);
00157 
00158 /** Apply a radial distortion using the given interpolation order (see imProcessResize). \n
00159  * Images must be of the same type and size. Returns zero if the counter aborted.
00160  *
00161  * \verbatim im.ProcessRadial(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, k1: number, order: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00162  * \verbatim im.ProcessRadialNew(image: imImage, k1: number, order: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00163  * \ingroup geom */
00164 int imProcessRadial(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, float k1, int order);
00165 
00166 /** Apply a swirl distortion using the given interpolation order (see imProcessResize). \n
00167  * Images must be of the same type and size. Returns zero if the counter aborted.
00168  *
00169  * \verbatim im.ProcessSwirl(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, k: number, order: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00170  * \verbatim im.ProcessSwirlNew(image: imImage, k: number, order: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00171  * \ingroup geom */
00172 int imProcessSwirl(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, float k1, int order);
00173 
00174 /** Split the image in two images, one containing the odd lines and other containing the even lines. \n
00175  * Images must be of the same type. Height of the output images must be half the height of the input image.
00176  * If the height of the input image is odd then the first image must have height equals to half+1.
00177  *
00178  * \verbatim im.ProcessInterlaceSplit(src_image: imImage, dst_image1: imImage, dst_image2: imImage) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00179  * \verbatim im.ProcessInterlaceSplitNew(image: imImage) -> new_image1: imImage, new_image2: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00180  * \ingroup geom */
00181 void imProcessInterlaceSplit(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image1, imImage* dst_image2);
00182

00184 
00185 /** \defgroup morphgray Morphology Operations for Gray Images
00186  * \par
00187  * See \ref im_process_loc.h
00188  * \ingroup process */
00189 
00190 /** Base gray morphology convolution. \n
00191  * Supports all data types except IM_CFLOAT. Can be applied on color images. \n
00192  * Kernel is always IM_INT. Use kernel size odd for better results. \n
00193  * Use -1 for don't care positions in kernel. Kernel values are added to image values, then \n
00194  * you can use the maximum or the minimum within the kernel area. \n
00195  * No border extensions are used. 
00196  * All the gray morphology operations use this function. \n
00197  * If the kernel image attribute "Description" exists it is used by the counter.
00198  *
00199  * \verbatim im.ProcessGrayMorphConvolve(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel: imImage, ismax: boolean) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00200  * \verbatim im.ProcessGrayMorphConvolveNew(image: imImage, kernel: imImage, ismax: boolean) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00201  * \ingroup morphgray */
00202 int imProcessGrayMorphConvolve(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, const imImage* kernel, int ismax);
00203 
00204 /** Gray morphology convolution with a kernel full of "0"s and use minimum value.
00205  *
00206  * \verbatim im.ProcessGrayMorphErode(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00207  * \verbatim im.ProcessGrayMorphErodeNew(image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00208  * \ingroup morphgray */
00209 int imProcessGrayMorphErode(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int kernel_size);
00210 
00211 /** Gray morphology convolution with a kernel full of "0"s and use maximum value.
00212  *
00213  * \verbatim im.ProcessGrayMorphDilate(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00214  * \verbatim im.ProcessGrayMorphDilateNew(image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00215  * \ingroup morphgray */
00216 int imProcessGrayMorphDilate(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int kernel_size);
00217 
00218 /** Erode+Dilate.
00219  *
00220  * \verbatim im.ProcessGrayMorphOpen(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00221  * \verbatim im.ProcessGrayMorphOpenNew(image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00222  * \ingroup morphgray */
00223 int imProcessGrayMorphOpen(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int kernel_size);
00224 
00225 /** Dilate+Erode.
00226  *
00227  * \verbatim im.ProcessGrayMorphClose(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00228  * \verbatim im.ProcessGrayMorphCloseNew(image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00229  * \ingroup morphgray */
00230 int imProcessGrayMorphClose(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int kernel_size);
00231 
00232 /** Open+Difference.
00233  *
00234  * \verbatim im.ProcessGrayMorphTopHat(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00235  * \verbatim im.ProcessGrayMorphTopHatNew(image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00236  * \ingroup morphgray */
00237 int imProcessGrayMorphTopHat(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int kernel_size);
00238 
00239 /** Close+Difference.
00240  *
00241  * \verbatim im.ProcessGrayMorphWell(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00242  * \verbatim im.ProcessGrayMorphWellNew(image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00243  * \ingroup morphgray */
00244 int imProcessGrayMorphWell(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int kernel_size);
00245 
00246 /** Difference(Erode, Dilate).
00247  *
00248  * \verbatim im.ProcessGrayMorphGradient(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00249  * \verbatim im.ProcessGrayMorphGradientNew(image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00250  * \ingroup morphgray */
00251 int imProcessGrayMorphGradient(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int kernel_size);
00252 
00253 
00254 
00255 /** \defgroup morphbin Morphology Operations for Binary Images
00256  * \par
00257  * See \ref im_process_loc.h
00258  * \ingroup process */
00259 
00260 /** Base binary morphology convolution. \n
00261  * Images are all IM_BINARY. Kernel is IM_INT, but values can be only 1, 0 or -1. Use kernel size odd for better results. \n
00262  * Hit white means hit=1 and miss=0, or else hit=0 and miss=1. \n
00263  * Use -1 for don't care positions in kernel. Kernel values are simply compared with image values. \n
00264  * The operation can be repeated by a number of iterations. 
00265  * The border is zero extended. \n
00266  * Almost all the binary morphology operations use this function.\n
00267  * If the kernel image attribute "Description" exists it is used by the counter.
00268  *
00269  * \verbatim im.ProcessBinMorphConvolve(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel: imImage, hit_white: boolean, iter: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00270  * \verbatim im.ProcessBinMorphConvolveNew(image: imImage, kernel: imImage, hit_white: boolean, iter: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00271  * \ingroup morphbin */
00272 int imProcessBinMorphConvolve(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, const imImage* kernel, int hit_white, int iter);
00273 
00274 /** Binary morphology convolution with a kernel full of "1"s and hit white.
00275  *
00276  * \verbatim im.ProcessBinMorphErode(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel_size: number, iter: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00277  * \verbatim im.ProcessBinMorphErodeNew(image: imImage, kernel_size: number, iter: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00278  * \ingroup morphbin */
00279 int imProcessBinMorphErode(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int kernel_size, int iter);
00280 
00281 /** Binary morphology convolution with a kernel full of "0"s and hit black.
00282  *
00283  * \verbatim im.ProcessBinMorphDilate(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel_size: number, iter: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00284  * \verbatim im.ProcessBinMorphDilateNew(image: imImage, kernel_size: number, iter: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00285  * \ingroup morphbin */
00286 int imProcessBinMorphDilate(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int kernel_size, int iter);
00287 
00288 /** Erode+Dilate.
00289  * When iteration is more than one it means Erode+Erode+Erode+...+Dilate+Dilate+Dilate+...
00290  *
00291  * \verbatim im.ProcessBinMorphOpen(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel_size: number, iter: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00292  * \verbatim im.ProcessBinMorphOpenNew(image: imImage, kernel_size: number, iter: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00293  * \ingroup morphbin */
00294 int imProcessBinMorphOpen(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int kernel_size, int iter);
00295 
00296 /** Dilate+Erode.
00297  *
00298  * \verbatim im.ProcessBinMorphClose(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel_size: number, iter: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00299  * \verbatim im.ProcessBinMorphCloseNew(image: imImage, kernel_size: number, iter: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00300  * \ingroup morphbin */
00301 int imProcessBinMorphClose(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int kernel_size, int iter);
00302 
00303 /** Erode+Difference. \n
00304  * The difference from the source image is applied only once.
00305  *
00306  * \verbatim im.ProcessBinMorphOutline(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel_size: number, iter: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00307  * \verbatim im.ProcessBinMorphOutlineNew(image: imImage, kernel_size: number, iter: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00308  * \ingroup morphbin */
00309 int imProcessBinMorphOutline(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int kernel_size, int iter);
00310 
00311 /** Thins the supplied binary image using Rosenfeld's parallel thinning algorithm. \n
00312  * Reference: \n
00313  * "Efficient Binary Image Thinning using Neighborhood Maps" \n
00314  * by Joseph M. Cychosz, 3ksnn64@ecn.purdue.edu              \n
00315  * in "Graphics Gems IV", Academic Press, 1994               \n
00316  * Not using OpenMP when enabled.
00317  *
00318  * \verbatim im.ProcessBinMorphThin(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00319  * \verbatim im.ProcessBinMorphThinNew(image: imImage) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00320  * \ingroup morphbin */
00321 void imProcessBinMorphThin(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image);
00322 
00323 
00324 
00325 /** \defgroup rank Rank Convolution Operations
00326  * \par
00327  * All the rank convolution use the same base function. Near the border the base function 
00328  * includes only the real image pixels in the rank. No border extensions are used.
00329  * \par
00330  * See \ref im_process_loc.h
00331  * \ingroup process */
00332 
00333 /** Rank convolution using the median value. \n
00334  * Returns zero if the counter aborted. \n
00335  * Supports all data types except IM_CFLOAT. Can be applied on color images.
00336  *
00337  * \verbatim im.ProcessMedianConvolve(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00338  * \verbatim im.ProcessMedianConvolveNew(image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00339  * \ingroup rank */
00340 int imProcessMedianConvolve(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int kernel_size);
00341 
00342 /** Rank convolution using (maximum-minimum) value. \n
00343  * Returns zero if the counter aborted. \n
00344  * Supports all data types except IM_CFLOAT. Can be applied on color images.
00345  *
00346  * \verbatim im.ProcessRangeConvolve(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00347  * \verbatim im.ProcessRangeConvolveNew(image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00348  * \ingroup rank */
00349 int imProcessRangeConvolve(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int kernel_size);
00350 
00351 /** Rank convolution using the closest maximum or minimum value. \n
00352  * Returns zero if the counter aborted. \n
00353  * Supports all data types except IM_CFLOAT. Can be applied on color images.
00354  *
00355  * \verbatim im.ProcessRankClosestConvolve(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00356  * \verbatim im.ProcessRankClosestConvolveNew(image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00357  * \ingroup rank */
00358 int imProcessRankClosestConvolve(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int kernel_size);
00359 
00360 /** Rank convolution using the maximum value. \n
00361  * Returns zero if the counter aborted. \n
00362  * Supports all data types except IM_CFLOAT. Can be applied on color images.
00363  *
00364  * \verbatim im.ProcessRankMaxConvolve(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00365  * \verbatim im.ProcessRankMaxConvolveNew(image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00366  * \ingroup rank */
00367 int imProcessRankMaxConvolve(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int kernel_size);
00368 
00369 /** Rank convolution using the minimum value. \n
00370  * Returns zero if the counter aborted. \n
00371  * Supports all data types except IM_CFLOAT. Can be applied on color images.
00372  *
00373  * \verbatim im.ProcessRankMinConvolve(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00374  * \verbatim im.ProcessRankMinConvolveNew(image: imImage, kernel_size: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00375  * \ingroup rank */
00376 int imProcessRankMinConvolve(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int kernel_size);

00378 /** Threshold using a rank convolution with a range contrast function. \n
00379  * Supports all integer IM_GRAY images as source, and IM_BINARY as destiny. \n
00380  * Local variable threshold by the method of Bernsen. \n
00381  * Extracted from XITE, Copyright 1991, Blab, UiO \n
00382  * http://www.ifi.uio.no/~blab/Software/Xite/
00383 \verbatim
00384   Reference:    
00385     Bernsen, J: "Dynamic thresholding of grey-level images"
00386                 Proc. of the 8th ICPR, Paris, Oct 1986, 1251-1255.
00387   Author:     Oivind Due Trier
00388 \endverbatim
00389  * Returns zero if the counter aborted.
00390  *
00391  * \verbatim im.ProcessRangeContrastThreshold(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel_size: number, min_range: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00392  * \verbatim im.ProcessRangeContrastThresholdNew(image: imImage, kernel_size: number, min_range: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00393  * \ingroup threshold */
00394 int imProcessRangeContrastThreshold(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int kernel_size, int min_range);
00395 
00396 /** Threshold using a rank convolution with a local max function.  \n
00397  * Returns zero if the counter aborted. \n
00398  * Supports all integer IM_GRAY images as source, and IM_BINARY as destiny.
00399  *
00400  * \verbatim im.ProcessLocalMaxThreshold(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel_size: number, min_level: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00401  * \verbatim im.ProcessLocalMaxThresholdNew(image: imImage, kernel_size: number, min_level: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00402  * \ingroup threshold */
00403 int imProcessLocalMaxThreshold(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, int kernel_size, int min_level);

00412 /** Base Convolution with a kernel. \n
00413  * Kernel can be IM_INT or IM_FLOAT, but always IM_GRAY. Use kernel size odd for better results. \n
00414  * Supports all data types. The border is mirrored. \n
00415  * Returns zero if the counter aborted. Most of the convolutions use this function.\n
00416  * If the kernel image attribute "Description" exists it is used by the counter.
00417  *
00418  * \verbatim im.ProcessConvolve(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel: imImage) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00419  * \verbatim im.ProcessConvolveNew(image: imImage, kernel: imImage) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00420  * \ingroup convolve */
00421 int imProcessConvolve(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, const imImage* kernel);
00422 
00423 /** Base convolution when the kernel is separable. Only the first line and the first column will be used. \n
00424  * Returns zero if the counter aborted.\n
00425  * If the kernel image attribute "Description" exists it is used by the counter.
00426  *
00427  * \verbatim im.ProcessConvolveSep(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel: imImage) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00428  * \verbatim im.ProcessConvolveSepNew(image: imImage, kernel: imImage) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00429  * \ingroup convolve */
00430 int imProcessConvolveSep(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, const imImage* kernel);
00431 
00432 /** Base Convolution with two kernels. The result is the magnitude of the result of each convolution. \n
00433  * Kernel can be IM_INT or IM_FLOAT, but always IM_GRAY. Use kernel size odd for better results. \n
00434  * Supports all data types. The border is mirrored. \n
00435  * Returns zero if the counter aborted. Most of the convolutions use this function.\n
00436  * If the kernel image attribute "Description" exists it is used by the counter.
00437  *
00438  * \verbatim im.ProcessConvolveDual(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel1, kernel2: imImage) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00439  * \verbatim im.ProcessConvolveDualNew(image: imImage, kernel1, kernel2: imImage) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00440  * \ingroup convolve */
00441 int imProcessConvolveDual(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, const imImage *kernel1, const imImage *kernel2);
00442 
00443 /** Repeats the convolution a number of times. \n
00444  * Returns zero if the counter aborted.\n
00445  * If the kernel image attribute "Description" exists it is used by the counter.
00446  *
00447  * \verbatim im.ProcessConvolveRep(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel: imImage, count: number) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00448  * \verbatim im.ProcessConvolveRepNew(image: imImage, kernel: imImage, count: number) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00449  * \ingroup convolve */
00450 int imProcessConvolveRep(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, const imImage* kernel, int count);
00451 
00452 /** Convolve with a kernel rotating it 8 times and getting the absolute maximum value. \n
00453  * Kernel must be square. \n
00454  * The rotation is implemented only for kernel sizes 3x3, 5x5 and 7x7. \n
00455  * Supports all data types except IM_CFLOAT.
00456  * Returns zero if the counter aborted.\n
00457  * If the kernel image attribute "Description" exists it is used by the counter.
00458  *
00459  * \verbatim im.ProcessCompassConvolve(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, kernel: imImage) -> counter: boolean [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00460  * \verbatim im.ProcessCompassConvolveNew(image: imImage, kernel: imImage) -> counter: boolean, new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00461  * \ingroup convolve */
00462 int imProcessCompassConvolve(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, imImage* kernel);
00463

00470 /** Difference(Gaussian1, Gaussian2). \n

00472  * but if source is IM_BYTE or IM_USHORT destiny image must be of type IM_INT.

00537 /** Finds the zero crossings of IM_INT and IM_FLOAT images. Crossings are marked with non zero values
00538  * indicating the intensity of the edge. It is usually used after a second derivative, laplace. \n
00539  * Extracted from XITE, Copyright 1991, Blab, UiO \n
00540  * http://www.ifi.uio.no/~blab/Software/Xite/
00541  *

00543  * \verbatim im.ProcessZeroCrossingNew(image: imImage) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00544  * \ingroup convolve */
00545 void imProcessZeroCrossing(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image);

00547 /** First part of the Canny edge detector. Includes the gaussian filtering and the nonmax suppression. \n
00548  * After using this you could apply a Hysteresis Threshold, see \ref imProcessHysteresisThreshold. \n
00549  * Image must be IM_BYTE/IM_GRAY. \n
00550  * Implementation from the book:
00551  \verbatim
00552     J. R. Parker
00553     "Algoritms for Image Processing and Computer Vision"
00554     WILEY
00555  \endverbatim
00556  *
00557  * \verbatim im.ProcessCanny(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, stddev: number) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00558  * \verbatim im.ProcessCannyNew(image: imImage, stddev: number) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00559  * \ingroup convolve */
00560 void imProcessCanny(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, float stddev);

00563  * If sdtdev is negative its magnitude will be used as the kernel size.
00564  *
00565  * \verbatim im.GaussianStdDev2KernelSize(stddev: number) -> kernel_size: number [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00566  * \ingroup convolve */

00569 /** Calculates the standard deviation given the kernel size.
00570  *
00571  * \verbatim im.GaussianKernelSize2StdDev(kernel_size: number) -> stddev: number [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00572  * \ingroup convolve */
00573 float imGaussianKernelSize2StdDev(int kernel_size);
00574 
00575 /** Edge enhancement using Unsharp mask. stddev control the gaussian filter, 
00576  *  amount controls how much the edges will enhance the image (0<amount<1), and
00577  *  threshold controls which edges will be considered, it compares to twice of the absolute size of the edge.
00578  *  Although very similar to \ref imProcessSharp, produces better results.
00579  *
00580  * \verbatim im.ProcessUnsharp(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, stddev: number, amount: number, threshold: number) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00581  * \verbatim im.ProcessUnsharpNew(image: imImage, stddev: number, amount: number, threshold: number) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00582  * \ingroup convolve */
00583 int imProcessUnsharp(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, float stddev, float amount, float threshold);
00584 
00585 /** Edge enhancement using Laplacian8 mask. 
00586  *  amount controls how much the edges will enhance the image (0<amount<1), and
00587  *  threshold controls which edges will be considered, it compares to twice of the absolute size of the edge.
00588  *
00589  * \verbatim im.ProcessSharp(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, amount: number, threshold: number) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00590  * \verbatim im.ProcessSharpNew(image: imImage, amount: number, threshold: number) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00591  * \ingroup convolve */
00592 int imProcessSharp(const imImage* src_image, imImage* dst_image, float amount, float threshold);
00593 
00594 /** Edge enhancement using a given kernel.
00595  *  If kernel has all positive values, then the unsharp technique is used, else sharp is used.
00596  *  amount controls how much the edges will enhance the image (0<amount<1), and
00597  *  threshold controls which edges will be considered, it compares to twice of the absolute size of the edge.
00598  *
00599  * \verbatim im.ProcessSharp(src_image: imImage, dst_image: imImage, amount: number, threshold: number) [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00600  * \verbatim im.ProcessSharpNew(image: imImage, amount: number, threshold: number) -> new_image: imImage [in Lua 5] \endverbatim
00601  * \ingroup convolve */
00602 int imProcessSharpKernel(const imImage* src_image, const imImage* kernel, imImage* dst_image, float amount, float threshold);
